President Bush made a high-profile appearance in Israel today.
He addressed a special session of the Israeli parliament as part of events marking the 60th anniversary of the founding of the Jewish state.
During his speech, Mr. Bush took a swing at one of Israel's enemies - Iran.
He made a statement that ruffled some feathers back home, particularly for one candidate trying to succeed him in the White House.
NPR's Jackie Northam reports from Jerusalem.
President Bush told a packed Knesset that the U.S.
and Israel have a, quote, ""unbreakable bond,"" and that America stands with Israel in firm opposition to Iran's nuclear ambitions.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: Permitting the world's leading sponsor of terror to possess the world's deadliest weapons would be an unforgivable betrayal for future generations.
For the sake of peace, the world must not allow Iran to have a nuclear weapon.
(Soundbite of applause)
The president received several rounds of applause and a standing ovation during his approximately 20-minute address.
There was also some dissent in the Knesset; several Israeli Arabs legislators were removed from parliament for protesting the Bush speech.
Meanwhile, in the West Bank, Palestinians marked the 60th anniversary with protest rallies.
Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas said the anniversary is a reminder of the struggle and the hardships of his people.
(Through translator) We are still here and there, deeply wounded in the land and holding on to our hope of return, freedom, and ending the hideous Israeli occupation of our land and people.
Our unambiguous message has been this: It is high time for our Palestinian people to enjoy liberation and peace.
President Bush says he wants a peace deal between Israel and the Palestinians before he leaves office.
And one reason for his visit to this area is to push the two sides to make more progress in their negotiations.
Still, Mr. Bush did not mention a peace deal in his speech.
In fact, he only once mentioned the Palestinians and what he envisions for them by the time Israel celebrates another 60 years of statehood.
The Palestinian people will have the homeland they long dreamed of and deserve, a democratic state that is governed by law and respects human rights and rejects terror.
Mr.
Bush says he also foresees a democratic Middle East and the defeat of al-Qaida and other extremist groups.
The president said terrorist groups are driven by power rather than religious beliefs, and he dismissed the argument that the U.S.
should try to negotiate with them.
Some seem to believe that we should negotiate with the terrorists and radicals, as if some ingenious argument will persuade them they had been wrong all along.
We've heard this foolish delusion before.
As Nazi tanks crossed into Poland in 1939 an America senator declared, Lord, if I could only have talked to Hitler, all this might have been avoided.
President Bush said that was a false comfort of appeasement, which has been repeatedly discredited by history.
Democratic Senator Barack Obama's campaign took offense at that statement.
Obama has said he would be willing to personally meet with Iran's leaders and other so-called rogue regimes.
Senator Obama accused Mr. Bush of a false political attack, but the White House denied the president's remarks were directed at the senator.
Jackie Northam, NPR News, Jerusalem.

This week, Fidel Castro gave his first interview since undergoing emergency surgery and seeding power to his brother Raul.
Fidel Castro appeared stronger than before but gave no indication he expects to return the power.
The end of Castro's rule and just the prospect of change in Cuba has cheered South Florida's exile community and others.
And as NPR's Greg Allen reports, those with the legal claims against the Cuban government are watching closely as well.
It's a point of principle among many Cuban exiles.
While they long for their former home, they refuse to return even for a visit until Castro is gone and change begins to come to Cuba.
While the public supports hunting in general, hunting black bear is still supported, but not as strong as maybe hunting for deer or other species.
Controversy has come to states that expand the hunting of black bears.
Animal rights activists tried using the courts to block a week-long hunt in New Jersey.
In December, they confronted sportsmen as they checked in their kills.
Part of the opposition is related to the method of bear hunting, which historically depends on a pack of dogs.
(SOUNDBITE OF DOGS BARKING)
In Polk County, Tennessee, where some hunting is already allowed, a nervous-looking bear has been chased 30 feet into a tree.
More could soon be running for their lives, and conservationists, like Ron Castle, aren't necessarily standing in the way.
Black bears have begun showing up in his neck of the Tennessee woods, which he himself helped preserve.
But he recognizes how much habitat his new neighbors need to survive.
Hunting would be more humane than allowing the bears to destroy their habitat and have their population collapse.
At this point, though, the concern is more about the human population and whether people will put up with black bears in their backyards.
For NPR News, I'm Blake Farmer, in Nashville.
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
Good morning.
This is the moment when Republicans either grab an opportunity - or lose it.
The party has ferociously opposed President Obama's health-care plans.
Whether a bill finally passes or not, Republicans believe they have gained from the energy of the debate.
That debate has revived a conservative base that's at the heart of the Republican Party.
But conservatives are going in so many different directions at once that they are becoming harder for the party to manage.
One place you can see the conflicts is in the primary elections for the U.S.
Senate, where Republicans are deciding the kinds of candidates they will support in the fall.
Here's NPR national political correspondent Mara Liasson.
If you're a Republican candidate running for Senate, you want to be able to say this...
We're the Tea Party candidate.
We're the one that is running against, basically, the establishment.
That was the front-runner in the Kentucky Republican senatorial primary, Rand Paul, son of congressman and libertarian hero Ron Paul.

Across the country in California's Senate primary, conservative Chuck DeVore, who's running against two better-funded and more moderate Republicans, praises the Tea Party's strength in this MSNBC interview.
(SOUNDBITE OF MSNBC NEWS PROGRAM)
...their passion for the Constitution, their passion for a basic, limited government.
All over the political map, the Republican establishment is trying to manage the anti-tax, anti-spending, anti-Washington sentiment that's behind the decentralized movement known as the Tea Parties.
The GOP is trying to capitalize on it, but it's not always in its control.
In Utah, it's gotten away from them.
The incumbent Republican senator there, Bob Bennett, is in danger of losing his seat to a Tea Party-backed challenger.
The conservative Club For Growth has been running this anti-Bennett ad.
